summary: So I’m listening the the Deathly Hallows audiobook in my car as I drive to and from work every day.
body:
So I’m listening the the Deathly Hallows audiobook in my car as I drive to and from work every day.

I started crying at a certain part (near the start of the book) just before I arrived at work.

One of my collegues asked if I was okay and I didn’t have the heart to tell them that I was crying over the death of a fictional character 😭

title: Io, sorella di Pippi Calzelunghe
body:
Avrei titolato questo pezzo “Elogio della differenza”, per una serie di differenze che sto per elencare.

Innanzitutto la differenza che fanno talune (ormai vere e proprie) istituzioni culturali nel loro instancabile e qualificato impegno, come la libreria L’Angolo delle Storie, in una Città - come la nostra – in cui il refrain è sempre “qui-non-si-fa-mai-niente”. (In Città si fa qualcosa, ma tra mille ostacoli e tanta scettica sufficienza di gran parte dell’opinione pubblica. L’importante è andare avanti, con eventi quali la rassegna Angolazioni - a cura di Emilia Cirillo ed Anna Catapano - locandina in basso).

La differenza è anche la portanza dell’incontro di giovedì sera, all’Angolo delle Storie -primo degli appuntamenti di Angolazioni - con Donatella Caione, fondatrice della Matilda Edizioni (nata dalla precedente esperienza di MammeOnLine). Donatella, pugliese si occupa di semi. In senso letterale e metaforico. Infatti, si occupa di grano (imprescindibile in una provincia come Capitanata) e si occupa di seminare salvifica differenza, in una società zeppa di pregiudizi di genere.

La grammatica la fa la… differenza, è anche il titolo di un libro pubblicato da Donatella (a cura dell’Associazione Donne in Rete di Foggia, tra cui la giovane Gemma Pacella e la combattente Teresa Manna, ospiti delle preziose Lia Tropeano e Consiglia Aquino), che spiega come il parlare informa e riforma il pensiero (già Vygotskji, ai primi del Novecento) e che le apposizioni solo al maschile perpetuano l’omologazione e i pregiudizi.

La lingua, si sa, è frutto dell’antropologia e di questa è, nel tempo, il maggior sostegno e linfa. Se osassimo cambiare (ovvero, usare con più rispetto delle persone e delle loro differenze) la grammatica, sicuramente le nostre strutture cognitive si modellerebbero a maggiore accettazione di una parità di ruoli, ma soprattutto di dignità.

Se si può imparare ad usare ’ministra’ (anche se evoca in me la minestra e Valeria Fedeli, la quale sottilizzava sul linguaggio di genere per sviare dagli argomenti pregnanti), ’avvocata’ (prendete l’invocazione della Salve Regina), sindaca o ’prefetta’, (no, ’medica’non riesco a sopportarlo, però!) tuttavia, non riesco ad accettare presidenta, in quanto in origine è un participio presente (in latino), con un’unica forma per il maschile ed il femminile: -ens, entis. Infatti, l’acqua è bollente, non bollenta; c’è un infante ed un’infante (in spagnolo, però, abbiamo infanta, ma si riferisce solo alle eredi femmine delle monarchie), un adolescente e un’adolescente.

Discorso abbastanza simile per il suffisso –essa. Se in alcune forme è da decenni attestato (professoressa, studentessa, avvocatessa, presidentessa), si deve pur ricordare che il suffisso –essa nasce come dispregiativo, per donne (o più globalmente per il genere femminile, come in tigressa, melonessa, polpessa) che si azzardavano ad imitare gli uomini (o non erano valide come i maschi, siano essi umanità, flora o fauna) ed andavano punite anche con gli appellativi.

Che dire dei sostantivi in –ore? Operatore/operatrice, calcolatore/calcolatrice, saldatore/saldatrice, programmatore/programmatrice, pulitore/pulitrice, mietitore/mietitrice hanno diverso significato se apposizione o attributo. (Per un attimo, per favore, riflettiamo anche su uso, significato e implicazioni di: segretario/segretaria, massaggiatore/massaggiatrice, battitore/battitrice, passeggiatore/passeggiatrice.)

Il discorso sulla grammatica è ampissimo e senza regole assestate (in Francia si stanno scannando sulla grammatica di genere). Nelle lingue come la nostra (tipo lo spagnolo, il già citato francese un po’ tutte le lingue romanze) diventa una questione finanche politica, laddove, per esempio, in tedesco la parola ’ragazza’ Madchen è di genere neutro, come anche Kind, bambino/a. Vabbe’, in tedesco der Mond (la luna) è maschile, die Sonne (il sole) è femminile, perché sono frutti dell’antropologia di quei luoghi, in cui il sole è flebile e gentile (die liebe Sonne) come una donzella e la luna si staglia netta nelle notti invernali come lo scudo di un guerriero. In giapponese, infine, anche i verbi si coniugano diversamente, se riferiti a donne o uomini.

La serata è stata troppo breve per parlare di tutte le differenze e le discriminazioni (o buona parte di esse) tra i generi. Tuttavia, per comprendere come siamo messi, basti solo pensare che a malapena il quattro percento della toponomastica italica è intitolata a donne e spessissimo si tratta di luoghi periferici, a volte pure privi di abitazioni.

La vera tragedia italiana di genere, però, è rappresentata dai femminicidi, più che dalle incongruenze grammaticali. La tragedia nella tragedia è che non si è ancora capaci di attuare un’efficace comunicazione per prevenire il crimine, educare le generazioni, riconoscere che siamo immersi in un pregiudizio cronico ed inestirpabile, dal linguaggio alla toponomastica, e perfino nella strutturazione dei messaggi di prevenzione (“Amore, se mi ammazzi, poi, chi picchi?”, come recita un infelice e recente spot).

Vorrei ricordare che a Licodìa Eubea (provincia di Catania) è stata intitolata una piazzetta (ed una sala universitaria) a Stefania Noce, una dolce ventenne, impegnata socialmente e politicamente sui temi dell’uguaglianza, ammazzata, assieme al nonno che la difendeva, dal suo fidanzato, geloso della sua indipendenza e della sua voglia di vita. Questo è il miglior esempio (peraltro unico) che abbiamo per onorare le vittime dei femminicidi e scardinare la toponomastica sessista.

Per quanto ci diamo da fare, tuttavia, la nostra società sta regredendo sui temi della parità e del rispetto, arrivando a storpiature ignobili, del tipo affermare che le malattie sessualmente trasmissibili siano evitabili con una buona igiene delle parti intime e della biancheria (sic, da un testo scolastico di scienza, segnalato da Donatella Caione). Vogliamo, inoltre, ricordare come la Legge 194 sia da anni oggetto di attacchi e ridimensionamenti fattuali (pandemia di obiettori), ovvero vogliamo menzionare gli ostacoli alla pillola del giorno dopo, nonché alle procedure di fecondazione assistita.

Ovviamente, una conquista non è mai per sempre e noi, generazioni post sessantottine, non sappiamo come difenderle. La società dopo le nostre nonne, mamme e sorelle maggiori non insegna come mantenere le conquiste civili, anzi mette sempre fortemente in dubbio già l’idea stessa di libertà civili, spesso discriminandole (unioni civili sì, matrimonio same sex no; adozioni per matrimonio sì, step-child adoption per unioni civili no).

Non siamo noi, cultura italiana moderna, che ha generato scrittrici come Astrid Lindgren, la cui Pippi Calzelunghe (il mio faro nel buio di genere del riflusso italiano, all’epoca della mia infanzia) ha insegnato a grandi e piccole l’indipendenza delle bambine, attraverso intelligentissime e sottili metafore. Tutt’al più abbiamo avuto la sensibile Bianca Pitzorno e la sua Extraterrestre alla pari, testo che però dobbiamo compensare con Senza paura, un libro a fumetti in cui Eva Kant c’insegna l’autodifesa.  
(Ricordo che Jo di Piccole donne, alla fine, si piega comunque al mainstream di moglie e madre.)

Ahimè, Pippi ed Eva sono importanti modelli di ruolo, tuttavia rimangono isolati, mentre il successo planetario è di un magico adolescente dal nome Harry Potter, non di una saggia e perspicacissima adolescente di nome Hermione Jean Granger.

Per carità, autodifesa è okay, ma cambiare la mentalità, no? Ecco come innanzitutto attraverso il ruolo della scuola, l’importanza dei messaggi giusti con un linguaggio corretto, e poi ancora mediante la testimonianza e l’esperienza di chi quei diritti li conquistò che si devono aiutare le generazioni ad imparare a riconoscere il labile confine tra affettuosità e avance, tra cordialità e molestia, tra gradimento e sopportazione.

PSP (Post scriptum personale): Io sono stata una ragazza fortunata. Non ho dovuto combattere ed essere costretta da società ed antropologia a soccombere a fratelli, perché ho solo sorelle e me la sono vista sempre alla pari: coraggio e uguaglianza è stata l’aria che abbiamo respirato crescendo. Son venuta su vivendo con modelli femminili di forza e resistenza, avendo avuto l’imprinting di una zia paterna che aveva barattato la dote con la possibilità di studiare per avere un buon lavoro e conquistare per sempre l’indipendenza; una bellissima donna dagli occhi verdi che sapeva andare a cavallo e tirare col fucile, cantare e recitare (si esibiva a RadioRai Puglia) e guidare trattori e auto gran turismo. Mia zia Raffaella fu una pioniera nell’arretratezza della Puglia dauna degli anni ’40 ed ella con tutte le indipendenti donne della mia famiglia sono la migliore educazione che potessi avere.

Donatella, pugliese si occupa di semi. In senso letterale e metaforico. Infatti, si occupa di grano (imprescindibile in una provincia come Capitanata) e si occupa di seminare salvifica differenza, in una società zeppa di pregiudizi di genere.

La grammatica la fa la… differenza, è anche il titolo di un libro pubblicato da Donatella (a cura dell’Associazione Donne in Rete di Foggia, tra cui la giovane Gemma Pacella e la combattente Teresa Manna, ospiti delle preziose Lia Tropeano e Consiglia Aquino), che spiega come il parlare informa e riforma il pensiero (già Vygotskji, ai primi del Novecento) e che le apposizioni solo al maschile perpetuano l’omologazione e i pregiudizi.

La lingua, si sa, è frutto dell’antropologia e di questa è, nel tempo, il maggior sostegno e linfa. Se osassimo cambiare (ovvero, usare con più rispetto delle persone e delle loro differenze) la grammatica, sicuramente le nostre strutture cognitive si modellerebbero a maggiore accettazione di una parità di ruoli, ma soprattutto di dignità.

Se si può imparare ad usare ’ministra’ (anche se evoca in me la minestra e Valeria Fedeli, la quale sottilizzava sul linguaggio di genere per sviare dagli argomenti pregnanti), ’avvocata’ (prendete l’invocazione della Salve Regina), sindaca o ’prefetta’, (no, ’medica’non riesco a sopportarlo, però!) tuttavia, non riesco ad accettare presidenta, in quanto in origine è un participio presente (in latino), con un’unica forma per il maschile ed il femminile: -ens, entis. Infatti, l’acqua è bollente, non bollenta; c’è un infante ed un’infante (in spagnolo, però, abbiamo infanta, ma si riferisce solo alle eredi femmine delle monarchie), un adolescente e un’adolescente.

Discorso abbastanza simile per il suffisso –essa. Se in alcune forme è da decenni attestato (professoressa, studentessa, avvocatessa, presidentessa), si deve pur ricordare che il suffisso –essa nasce come dispregiativo, per donne (o più globalmente per il genere femminile, come in tigressa, melonessa, polpessa) che si azzardavano ad imitare gli uomini (o non erano valide come i maschi, siano essi umanità, flora o fauna) ed andavano punite anche con gli appellativi.

Che dire dei sostantivi in –ore? Operatore/operatrice, calcolatore/calcolatrice, saldatore/saldatrice, programmatore/programmatrice, pulitore/pulitrice, mietitore/mietitrice hanno diverso significato se apposizione o attributo. (Per un attimo, per favore, riflettiamo anche su uso, significato e implicazioni di: segretario/segretaria, massaggiatore/massaggiatrice, battitore/battitrice, passeggiatore/passeggiatrice.)

Il discorso sulla grammatica è ampissimo e senza regole assestate (in Francia si stanno scannando sulla grammatica di genere). Nelle lingue come la nostra (tipo lo spagnolo, il già citato francese un po’ tutte le lingue romanze) diventa una questione finanche politica, laddove, per esempio, in tedesco la parola ’ragazza’ Madchen è di genere neutro, come anche Kind, bambino/a. Vabbe’, in tedesco der Mond (la luna) è maschile, die Sonne (il sole) è femminile, perché sono frutti dell’antropologia di quei luoghi, in cui il sole è flebile e gentile (die liebe Sonne) come una donzella e la luna si staglia netta nelle notti invernali come lo scudo di un guerriero. In giapponese, infine, anche i verbi si coniugano diversamente, se riferiti a donne o uomini.

La serata è stata troppo breve per parlare di tutte le differenze e le discriminazioni (o buona parte di esse) tra i generi. Tuttavia, per comprendere come siamo messi, basti solo pensare che a malapena il quattro percento della toponomastica italica è intitolata a donne e spessissimo si tratta di luoghi periferici, a volte pure privi di abitazioni.

La vera tragedia italiana di genere, però, è rappresentata dai femminicidi, più che dalle incongruenze grammaticali. La tragedia nella tragedia è che non si è ancora capaci di attuare un’efficace comunicazione per prevenire il crimine, educare le generazioni, riconoscere che siamo immersi in un pregiudizio cronico ed inestirpabile, dal linguaggio alla toponomastica, e perfino nella strutturazione dei messaggi di prevenzione (“Amore, se mi ammazzi, poi, chi picchi?”, come recita un infelice e recente spot).

Vorrei ricordare che a Licodìa Eubea (provincia di Catania) è stata intitolata una piazzetta (ed una sala universitaria) a Stefania Noce, una dolce ventenne, impegnata socialmente e politicamente sui temi dell’uguaglianza, ammazzata, assieme al nonno che la difendeva, dal suo fidanzato, geloso della sua indipendenza e della sua voglia di vita. Questo è il miglior esempio (peraltro unico) che abbiamo per onorare le vittime dei femminicidi e scardinare la toponomastica sessista.

Per quanto ci diamo da fare, tuttavia, la nostra società sta regredendo sui temi della parità e del rispetto, arrivando a storpiature ignobili, del tipo affermare che le malattie sessualmente trasmissibili siano evitabili con una buona igiene delle parti intime e della biancheria (sic, da un testo scolastico di scienza, segnalato da Donatella Caione). Vogliamo, inoltre, ricordare come la Legge 194 sia da anni oggetto di attacchi e ridimensionamenti fattuali (pandemia di obiettori), ovvero vogliamo menzionare gli ostacoli alla pillola del giorno dopo, nonché alle procedure di fecondazione assistita.

Ovviamente, una conquista non è mai per sempre e noi, generazioni post sessantottine, non sappiamo come difenderle. La società dopo le nostre nonne, mamme e sorelle maggiori non insegna come mantenere le conquiste civili, anzi mette sempre fortemente in dubbio già l’idea stessa di libertà civili, spesso discriminandole (unioni civili sì, matrimonio same sex no; adozioni per matrimonio sì, step-child adoption per unioni civili no).

Non siamo noi, cultura italiana moderna, che ha generato scrittrici come Astrid Lindgren, la cui Pippi Calzelunghe (il mio faro nel buio di genere del riflusso italiano, all’epoca della mia infanzia) ha insegnato a grandi e piccole l’indipendenza delle bambine, attraverso intelligentissime e sottili metafore. Tutt’al più abbiamo avuto la sensibile Bianca Pitzorno e la sua Extraterrestre alla pari, testo che però dobbiamo compensare con Senza paura, un libro a fumetti in cui Eva Kant c’insegna l’autodifesa.  
(Ricordo che Jo di Piccole donne, alla fine, si piega comunque al mainstream di moglie e madre.)

Ahimè, Pippi ed Eva sono importanti modelli di ruolo, tuttavia rimangono isolati, mentre il successo planetario è di un magico adolescente dal nome Harry Potter, non di una saggia e perspicacissima adolescente di nome Hermione Jean Granger.

Per carità, autodifesa è okay, ma cambiare la mentalità, no? Ecco come innanzitutto attraverso il ruolo della scuola, l’importanza dei messaggi giusti con un linguaggio corretto, e poi ancora mediante la testimonianza e l’esperienza di chi quei diritti li conquistò che si devono aiutare le generazioni ad imparare a riconoscere il labile confine tra affettuosità e avance, tra cordialità e molestia, tra gradimento e sopportazione.

PSP (Post scriptum personale): Io sono stata una ragazza fortunata. Non ho dovuto combattere ed essere costretta da società ed antropologia a soccombere a fratelli, perché ho solo sorelle e me la sono vista sempre alla pari: coraggio e uguaglianza è stata l’aria che abbiamo respirato crescendo. Son venuta su vivendo con modelli femminili di forza e resistenza, avendo avuto l’imprinting di una zia paterna che aveva barattato la dote con la possibilità di studiare per avere un buon lavoro e conquistare per sempre l’indipendenza; una bellissima donna dagli occhi verdi che sapeva andare a cavallo e tirare col fucile, cantare e recitare (si esibiva a RadioRai Puglia) e guidare trattori e auto gran turismo. Mia zia Raffaella fu una pioniera nell’arretratezza della Puglia dauna degli anni ’40 ed ella con tutte le indipendenti donne della mia famiglia sono la migliore educazione che potessi avere.

summary: What Have We Done? {George Weasley x Reader} - Part One
title: What Have We Done? {George Weasley x Reader} - Part One
body:
Summary: In the aftermath of a regrettable drunken kiss, (Y/N) (Y/L/N) and George Weasley need to come to terms with what it might mean for their relationship.

Masterlist | Series Masterlist

Warnings: None besides a tad of angst.

Word count: 1.8k

October 15th, 1995

What the hell had you been thinking?

Flashes of last night came back to you: the warm feeling you get after consuming alcohol. Gryffindor students dancing around the common room with the log fire crackling away in the fireplace. Lee Jordan standing up on a table, singing some words to an old wizarding song you didn’t know but everyone else seemed to. Flinging your arms around a tall, redheaded figure that stood so close that you could smell the cologne on his body. The slight mumbling of words falling out of your mouth, and your lips pressed against the lips of your best friend.

You had kissed George Weasley. George, bloody, Weasley.

You rolled over in your bed, burying your face deeper into your pillow. You couldn’t believe that you had done that. The embarrassment over the entire thing trumped the headache you felt coming on. You wanted to sink deep into your bed and stay there for the rest of your life.

Oh God, George. What did George think? Right now, he probably thought you were a bloody idiot. The alcohol had taken a lot of your memories of the night, leaving you with only flashes here and there. If only you could just forget that the kiss had ever happened, maybe things could go back to normal. But no matter how much you forgot it, it didn’t take away from the fact that the kiss did happen.

The memory was so vivid in your head, each movement precise and each colour as real as in the moment it had happened. You could still hear the sound of the raindrops hitting the window behind the two of you as your fingers made their way into his hair. Your fingers had played with each soft, ginger strand as you closed your eyes, letting instinct take control of the kiss. George had placed a hand on your back and one on your side, his lips still in shock from the suddenness of the kiss. And that was when everything went black, each moment after lost to the stupidity of your drunken state.

You wanted to throw something or beat your hands against the wall. Each time the thought crept back into your mind it was like it brought a new wave of frustration with it. You had let your guard down in a moment of stupidity and recklessness, leaving your most prized and loving relationship in the world at risk.

Over the course of your seven-year friendship, you had never once let your guard down. It wasn’t like you didn’t want to, sometimes it was all you could think about. You’d fight with yourself, your brain and heart in constant battle, fighting out for whether you should be rational or put everything on the line. There were moments where you wanted nothing more than to just kiss him full on the mouth and let a confession of your feelings slip from your lips. From the moment that you, George and Fred has stepped off the Hogwarts Express in your first year, you had been joined at the hip. If you tried at a relationship and failed, not only would you have lost a lover, but also the best friend you had ever known.

And there were moments, wherein the struggle, you almost let everything go. They always seemed to be the simple moments, where nothing out of the ordinary had happened and yet you could feel your heart skip a beat as time began to slow down. George might have a particular look on his face or be wearing one of his adorable Weasley sweaters. He could be walking down the corridor in your direction, the biggest smirk playing on his lips. He could be dancing around and acting like the complete and lovable goofball that he was and you could almost hear the words slip from your lips and see the look in George’s eyes when he heard them. 

It was like your heart was stuck in your throat. You felt like you were going to be sick with a mixture of your hangover and the memory of what had occurred last night. You swung your feet over the side of your bed, letting the cool temperature of the stone floor flow into your feet. You stood up, grabbed your dressing gown and made your way for Hermione’s room.

Boy, was she going to love this.

George rolled over onto his back so that he looked straight up into the dormitory’s ceiling. He hadn’t stopped thinking of everything that had happened last night.

The second that George had laid his head down on his pillow, he knew that he wasn’t going to get any sleep. His mind was spinning, going over every detail that had passed. He kept picturing (Y/N) wrapping her arms around his neck, pulling him so close that he could smell the perfume that she wore. He remembered her nose touching the strands of hair around his ear as she kissed him there. He thought about the words she had spoken through giggles, and finally, he pictured the moment where she had placed her lips on his own and kissed him full on the mouth.

She was so drunk that he wasn’t sure if her actions and words were genuine, brought out with the assistance of the amount of alcohol she had consumed. Or if, in fact, it was just her drunken state that had made her mumble the little words in his ear and bring her lips to his.

He could still hear her words, echoing around his head and making his heart beat faster just at the thought. “I like you, George,” she had said, in an almost slurred way. “I’ve liked you for years.”

“You’re just drunk, (Y/N),” he had told her. He watched her lips turn into a smile before she playfully hit him on the arm.

“I am not! I’m telling the truth, George. I do like you.”

And that was when she had leaned in, and before George could do anything, she had her arms wrapped around him and her fingers playing in his hair. He wanted to keep kissing her, to take her up to his room and lay her down on his bed. But his conscience wouldn’t let him. She was drunk and didn’t know what she was doing. She probably wouldn’t even remember it in the morning. He’d pulled his body away from hers, causing an annoyed expression to cross (Y/N)’s face.

“Come on, (Y/N),” He had said, tucking a strand of her loose (H/C) behind her ear. “It’s time for bed.”

Looking back now, George knew he had done the right thing. It wouldn’t have been fair on (Y/N) to take advantage of her like that. But he couldn’t shake the feeling that he had let his chance go, that maybe she would have remembered. Maybe she would be laying here right now beside him, muttering the same things in his ear.

What would he do when he saw her next? Ask her if she could remember what had passed the night before? A part of him hoped that she did and that she would tell him that she had meant what she said. Another part hoped that she didn’t, in case she had, in fact, been too drunk for him to put any truth behind her words. 

George turned his head to look at Fred asleep in the bed beside him. He opened his mouth to wake him up, but when he wanted to speak, he felt the words dry up in his mouth. He told Fred pretty much everything, but this time, he felt like he just couldn’t get the words past his lips.

“Hermione,” You whispered, letting your voice cut through your friend’s dormitory. It was cold in the girl’s tower and you could see your frizzy-haired friend look up from her book, her pink dressing gown tied tightly around her waist. When she saw you, her eyebrows knitted together.

“What?” she whispered back. Next to her, Lavender Brown stirred and turned over in her sleep. You looked back at Hermione and motioned for her to follow you down into the common room.

You lead her down the cobblestone steps until you reached the red and golden room, the coals from last night’s fire cold and black. The normally lively room was dead empty, no one else daring to get up this early on a Sunday morning. “What is it?” Hermione asked.

“Okay, look,” You stated, swallowing. Your heart was beginning to thump loudly in your chest, bringing heat to your cheeks and ears. “I’m going to tell you something and you need to promise me you won’t freak out and tell anyone.”

Confusion crossed Hermione’s face. “Of course I won’t. So, what is it?”

“Okay.” You didn’t want to admit that you had been so stupid to do a thing like that, but there was no way you could keep it in any longer without it eating you up. “Remember the party last night and how I got really drunk?”

“You could say that,” Hermione quipped. “I saw you get up on the table with Dean Thomas and sing a duet of ‘Don’t go Breaking my Heart.’”

“I did that?” You said, surprised. “Okay, that’s beside the point. Last night I did something stupid.”

“And that wasn’t?”

“Okay, Hermione. I didn’t come here to be lectured.” You rolled your eyes and took a deep breath. You couldn’t look at her as you gathered the courage to get the words out, your heart beginning to beat faster with each moment that passed. “I - I. I kissed George.”

Hermione’s eyes went wide immediately. For a moment, she didn’t say anything, her initial shock taking the words from her mouth. “How? How did it happen?”

“I can’t exactly remember,” You said. “I can’t remember most things from last night, to be honest.”

“Do you remember doing anything more than kissing?”

“No. No, I don’t think we did.” You said, shaking your head. “Was George that drunk last night? I can’t remember.”

Hermione shook her head, her arms still crossed. “I don’t think so. I don’t recall seeing him that drunk. I know Fred was though.”

“Oh, God,” You muttered. “What have I done, Hermione? I’ve completely stuffed everything up.”

You shut your eyes, pressing a hand to your forehead. The whole thing had sent your mind hurtling from thought to thought at a hundred miles per hour. You felt like crying from embarrassment and frustration, every thought making you want to rip each strand of hair out one by one.

“I’m going to ask you a question, (Y/N),” Hermione said, a look of earnestness in her eyes. “And it’ll do you best to answer it truthfully.”

You took a sharp intake of breath. You knew exactly what the question would be, it wasn’t that hard to figure it out after the subject of the conversation.

“Do you like him?”

You took your eyes off the ground and raised them so that they were looking straight into hers. You swallowed and said what you had been frightened to say for years.

“Yes.”

There’s part one! I’m not too sure how it turned out so I’d be so happy for some feedback. Thank you!

Alpha Tags: @xinyourdreamsx

Beta Tags: @reeseweese @girlrauuuhl @all1496 @do-i-look-ok @disneyprincessbuffyannesummers @lexi-laz @bees-love-books @faliwi @nyx-the-black-wolf @what-do-the-stars-hide @aboutpotter @maxley @shamelesssaladhumanscissors @chocok22 @knreidy1  @dooriha @abahena2020  @kealohilani-tepise  @designfailure56  @fanfictionrecommendations-com

~~Tess~~

Confusion crossed Hermione’s face. “Of course I won’t. So, what is it?”

“Okay.” You didn’t want to admit that you had been so stupid to do a thing like that, but there was no way you could keep it in any longer without it eating you up. “Remember the party last night and how I got really drunk?”

“You could say that,” Hermione quipped. “I saw you get up on the table with Dean Thomas and sing a duet of ‘Don’t go Breaking my Heart.’”

“I did that?” You said, surprised. “Okay, that’s beside the point. Last night I did something stupid.”

“And that wasn’t?”

“Okay, Hermione. I didn’t come here to be lectured.” You rolled your eyes and took a deep breath. You couldn’t look at her as you gathered the courage to get the words out, your heart beginning to beat faster with each moment that passed. “I - I. I kissed George.”

Hermione’s eyes went wide immediately. For a moment, she didn’t say anything, her initial shock taking the words from her mouth. “How? How did it happen?”

“I can’t exactly remember,” You said. “I can’t remember most things from last night, to be honest.”

“Do you remember doing anything more than kissing?”

“No. No, I don’t think we did.” You said, shaking your head. “Was George that drunk last night? I can’t remember.”

Hermione shook her head, her arms still crossed. “I don’t think so. I don’t recall seeing him that drunk. I know Fred was though.”

“Oh, God,” You muttered. “What have I done, Hermione? I’ve completely stuffed everything up.”

You shut your eyes, pressing a hand to your forehead. The whole thing had sent your mind hurtling from thought to thought at a hundred miles per hour. You felt like crying from embarrassment and frustration, every thought making you want to rip each strand of hair out one by one.

“I’m going to ask you a question, (Y/N),” Hermione said, a look of earnestness in her eyes. “And it’ll do you best to answer it truthfully.”

You took a sharp intake of breath. You knew exactly what the question would be, it wasn’t that hard to figure it out after the subject of the conversation.

“Do you like him?”

You took your eyes off the ground and raised them so that they were looking straight into hers. You swallowed and said what you had been frightened to say for years.

“Yes.”

There’s part one! I’m not too sure how it turned out so I’d be so happy for some feedback. Thank you!

Summary: In the aftermath of a regrettable drunken kiss, (Y/N) (Y/L/N) and George Weasley need to come to terms with what it might mean for their relationship.

Masterlist | Series Masterlist

Warnings: None besides a tad of angst.

Word count: 1.8k

October 15th, 1995

What the hell had you been thinking?

Flashes of last night came back to you: the warm feeling you get after consuming alcohol. Gryffindor students dancing around the common room with the log fire crackling away in the fireplace. Lee Jordan standing up on a table, singing some words to an old wizarding song you didn’t know but everyone else seemed to. Flinging your arms around a tall, redheaded figure that stood so close that you could smell the cologne on his body. The slight mumbling of words falling out of your mouth, and your lips pressed against the lips of your best friend.

You had kissed George Weasley. George, bloody, Weasley.

You rolled over in your bed, burying your face deeper into your pillow. You couldn’t believe that you had done that. The embarrassment over the entire thing trumped the headache you felt coming on. You wanted to sink deep into your bed and stay there for the rest of your life.

Oh God, George. What did George think? Right now, he probably thought you were a bloody idiot. The alcohol had taken a lot of your memories of the night, leaving you with only flashes here and there. If only you could just forget that the kiss had ever happened, maybe things could go back to normal. But no matter how much you forgot it, it didn’t take away from the fact that the kiss did happen.

The memory was so vivid in your head, each movement precise and each colour as real as in the moment it had happened. You could still hear the sound of the raindrops hitting the window behind the two of you as your fingers made their way into his hair. Your fingers had played with each soft, ginger strand as you closed your eyes, letting instinct take control of the kiss. George had placed a hand on your back and one on your side, his lips still in shock from the suddenness of the kiss. And that was when everything went black, each moment after lost to the stupidity of your drunken state.

You wanted to throw something or beat your hands against the wall. Each time the thought crept back into your mind it was like it brought a new wave of frustration with it. You had let your guard down in a moment of stupidity and recklessness, leaving your most prized and loving relationship in the world at risk.

Over the course of your seven-year friendship, you had never once let your guard down. It wasn’t like you didn’t want to, sometimes it was all you could think about. You’d fight with yourself, your brain and heart in constant battle, fighting out for whether you should be rational or put everything on the line. There were moments where you wanted nothing more than to just kiss him full on the mouth and let a confession of your feelings slip from your lips. From the moment that you, George and Fred has stepped off the Hogwarts Express in your first year, you had been joined at the hip. If you tried at a relationship and failed, not only would you have lost a lover, but also the best friend you had ever known.

And there were moments, wherein the struggle, you almost let everything go. They always seemed to be the simple moments, where nothing out of the ordinary had happened and yet you could feel your heart skip a beat as time began to slow down. George might have a particular look on his face or be wearing one of his adorable Weasley sweaters. He could be walking down the corridor in your direction, the biggest smirk playing on his lips. He could be dancing around and acting like the complete and lovable goofball that he was and you could almost hear the words slip from your lips and see the look in George’s eyes when he heard them. 

It was like your heart was stuck in your throat. You felt like you were going to be sick with a mixture of your hangover and the memory of what had occurred last night. You swung your feet over the side of your bed, letting the cool temperature of the stone floor flow into your feet. You stood up, grabbed your dressing gown and made your way for Hermione’s room.

Boy, was she going to love this.

George rolled over onto his back so that he looked straight up into the dormitory’s ceiling. He hadn’t stopped thinking of everything that had happened last night.

The second that George had laid his head down on his pillow, he knew that he wasn’t going to get any sleep. His mind was spinning, going over every detail that had passed. He kept picturing (Y/N) wrapping her arms around his neck, pulling him so close that he could smell the perfume that she wore. He remembered her nose touching the strands of hair around his ear as she kissed him there. He thought about the words she had spoken through giggles, and finally, he pictured the moment where she had placed her lips on his own and kissed him full on the mouth.

She was so drunk that he wasn’t sure if her actions and words were genuine, brought out with the assistance of the amount of alcohol she had consumed. Or if, in fact, it was just her drunken state that had made her mumble the little words in his ear and bring her lips to his.

He could still hear her words, echoing around his head and making his heart beat faster just at the thought. “I like you, George,” she had said, in an almost slurred way. “I’ve liked you for years.”

“You’re just drunk, (Y/N),” he had told her. He watched her lips turn into a smile before she playfully hit him on the arm.

“I am not! I’m telling the truth, George. I do like you.”

And that was when she had leaned in, and before George could do anything, she had her arms wrapped around him and her fingers playing in his hair. He wanted to keep kissing her, to take her up to his room and lay her down on his bed. But his conscience wouldn’t let him. She was drunk and didn’t know what she was doing. She probably wouldn’t even remember it in the morning. He’d pulled his body away from hers, causing an annoyed expression to cross (Y/N)’s face.

“Come on, (Y/N),” He had said, tucking a strand of her loose (H/C) behind her ear. “It’s time for bed.”

Looking back now, George knew he had done the right thing. It wouldn’t have been fair on (Y/N) to take advantage of her like that. But he couldn’t shake the feeling that he had let his chance go, that maybe she would have remembered. Maybe she would be laying here right now beside him, muttering the same things in his ear.

What would he do when he saw her next? Ask her if she could remember what had passed the night before? A part of him hoped that she did and that she would tell him that she had meant what she said. Another part hoped that she didn’t, in case she had, in fact, been too drunk for him to put any truth behind her words. 

George turned his head to look at Fred asleep in the bed beside him. He opened his mouth to wake him up, but when he wanted to speak, he felt the words dry up in his mouth. He told Fred pretty much everything, but this time, he felt like he just couldn’t get the words past his lips.

“Hermione,” You whispered, letting your voice cut through your friend’s dormitory. It was cold in the girl’s tower and you could see your frizzy-haired friend look up from her book, her pink dressing gown tied tightly around her waist. When she saw you, her eyebrows knitted together.

“What?” she whispered back. Next to her, Lavender Brown stirred and turned over in her sleep. You looked back at Hermione and motioned for her to follow you down into the common room.

You lead her down the cobblestone steps until you reached the red and golden room, the coals from last night’s fire cold and black. The normally lively room was dead empty, no one else daring to get up this early on a Sunday morning. “What is it?” Hermione asked.

Hermione shook her head, her arms still crossed. “I don’t think so. I don’t recall seeing him that drunk. I know Fred was though.”
